Graphical abstract The targeted conversion of furfural (FA) over inexpensive catalyst is a critical and challenging project. Herein, CoNi alloy catalysts (xCoyNi/C) were prepared through one-step pyrolysis of metal–organic frameworks and used in furfural (FA) hydrogenation to tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (TFOL). The formation of CoNi alloy leads to a reconfiguration of the electronic structure on the metal surface, which affects the adsorption of functional groups on FA and furfuryl alcohol (FOL). In situ FT-IR analysis and DFT calculations verify that bimetallic CoNi alloy catalyst exhibits more suitable reactants adsorption and hydrogenation rate in comparison with the monometallic Co and monometallic Ni catalysts. Meanwhile, CoNi alloy significantly reduces the activation barrier from FOL to TFOL. Hence, the 1Co1Ni/C catalyst gives the highest TFOL yield of > 99 %. This study provides a simple strategy for the preparation of alloy catalysts for tuning product selectivity and presents practical potential for upgrading biomass-derived platform molecules. Keywords CoNi alloy Furfural Tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol Electron transfer Adsorption state Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction On the premise of the global commitment to combating climate change, reducing global carbon emissions and lowering dependence on fossil energy are the directions of each country's efforts. Biomass, as a renewable organic carbon resource, can be applied to produce chemicals essential for economic and social development, which helps to conquer the energy crisis and environmental issues [1–3]. Typically, furfural (FA) is a key platform molecule derived from the hydrolytic dehydration of hemicellulose, which has attracted extensive attention owing to its high reactivity of the furan ring and carbonyl group [4–6]. FA can be transformed into many value-added chemicals by catalytic hydrogenation, such as furfuryl alcohol (FOL), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (TFOL), cyclopentanone (CPO), 1,5-pentanediol (1,5-PDO) and 1,2-pentanediol (1,2-PDO), etc [7,8]. Among them, TFOL is an important chemical intermediate that can be utilized to synthesize industrial resins, printing inks, lysine, and electronic cleaners [9,10]. Therefore, it is valuable and meaningful to develop an efficient and environmentally friendly catalyst for the hydrogenation of FA to TFOL. Normally, in the FA hydrogenation reaction, the strong adsorption of different functional groups on the metal surface leads to different products, and the adsorption strength of the reactants on the metal surface also affects the reaction rate [11,12]. In addition, the FA hydrogenation process may involve multi-step reactions (e.g., FA hydrogenation to TFOL includes two-step reactions [13]). Thus, the control of the reaction rate is particularly important, otherwise side reactions or over reactions may occur in multi-step reactions. Therefore, the targeted conversion of FA is facing challenge since that it is difficult to control the adsorption of specific functional groups on the metal surface and to control the reaction rate by modulating the activity of the metal [14]. The research on FA hydrogenation to TFOL mainly focused on noble metal or non-noble metal and noble metal combination catalysts, such as Ru [15,16], Pd [17,18], and Pd-Co [9], which presented excellent TFOL yields under relatively mild reaction conditions. Although noble metal catalysts showed excellent catalytic performance, high cost and scarce resources limited the application. The non-noble metal Ni-based catalyst exhibited good selectivity to TFOL, but the reaction must be carried out under harsh reaction conditions since that the active H* is difficult to desorb from the Ni surface [19,20]. In contrast, H* can be dissociated well on Co metal catalysts, leading to high hydrogenation activity [21]. However, the Co surface showed stronger adsorption of C = O rather than furan rings, leading to a low yield of TFOL [22]. As reported, the adsorption state of reactant on metal surface can be affected by adjusting the electronic structure of metal surface [23–25]. In general, the introduction of a second metal is an effective strategy, especially the introduction of a reductive metal to form alloy, which can effectively adjust the electronic structure of the metal surface to enhance the catalytic performance of bimetallic or multimetallic catalysts. Such as Co-Cu [26,27], Co-Ni [28–30], Ni-Fe [31,32] and NixSny [8,33] exhibited better catalytic performance than monometallic catalysts. Tang et al. discovered that the addition of Cu decreased the d-band center of Ni by constructing Ni-Cu alloy catalyst (NiCux/C), not only promoting the desorption of H* from Ni surface to improve the catalytic activity but also changing the adsorption orientation of FA on the catalyst to regulate the product selectivity [34]. Peng et al. reported that the synergetic effect between Ni and Co enhanced the ability for hydrogen adsorption and activation, thus increasing the surface concentration of active H* and prompting the catalytic activity toward 1,5-PDO [29]. These results provided ideas for optimizing the catalytic performance for FA hydrogenation. Herein, the aim of this study is to prepare Co-Ni bimetallic catalysts (xCoyNi/C) derived from metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and apply in selective hydrogenation of FA to TFOL. The effects of Co-Ni alloy and adsorption configuration of xCoyNi/C will be studied in depth in comparison with monometallic catalyst (Co/C and Ni/C) based on characterization and DFT calculation results. Moreover, the study of the structure–activity relationship of Co-Ni bimetallic catalyst will be carried out. This work may provide new ideas for the synthesis of high-performance bimetallic catalysts in biomass platform molecules catalytic hydrogenation conversion. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 99 %), 1,3,5 trimeric acid (H3BTC, 98 %), N, N-Dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.5 %) and furfural (C5H4O2, 99 %) were purchased from Shanghai Maclin Biological Technology Co., Ltd. Ethanol (EtOH, 99.5 %) was purchased from Hunan Huihong Reagent Co. Ltd. Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O, 99 %), isopropanol (C3H8O, 99.7 %), n-octanol (C8H12O, 99 %) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 96 %) were purchased from Xilong Scientific Co., Ltd. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Typically, Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O with a certain molar ratio of Co2+/Ni2+ metal salts (The total molar amount of Co2+ and Ni2+ is fixed to 5 mmol, x/y represents the molar ratio of Co2+/Ni2+) were dissolved in 50 mL DMF and the solution was heated to 120 °C. Furthermore, the H3BTC (5 mmol) was added to the above solution and stirred for 15 h. And then, the solution was centrifuged and washed three times with ethanol, and dried at 80 °C for 24 h to obtain Co-Ni-MOF. After that, the obtained Co-Ni-MOF was pushed into tubular furnace in N2 atmosphere and heated to 500 °C at 10 °C min−1 for 2 h to acquire the xCoyNi/C catalyst. Comparison samples 1Co1Ni/C-AC and 1Co1Ni/C-CE catalysts were prepared by replacing H3BTC with activated carbon and cellulose, respectively. 2.3 Catalytic test Furfural hydrogenation was carried out in a 25 mL stainless steel autoclave. Typically, 40 mg catalyst, 0.1 g furfural and 6 mL isopropanol solvent were added in the reactor lining. The autoclave reactor was degassed and purged with H2 for 4 times and then pressurized with H2 to the set values. Then, the autoclave was heated to the required temperature and then stirred at 400r/min. After the reaction, the products were collected and analyzed by gas chromatogram (GC, Agilent 7820A) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and an Agilent-DB-1701 capillary column. The conversion and selectivity were calculated as follows: (1) C o n v e r s i o n = m o l e s o f s u b s t r a t e r e a c t e d m o l e s o f s u b s t r a t e × 100 % (2) S e l e c t i v i t y = g e n e r a t e d p r o d u c t i n m o l a r m o l e s o f s u b s t r a t e r e a c t e d × 100 % To further analyze the turn over frequency (TOF) of conversion of the reactant, the conversion of FA was controlled below 10 %. The TOF value referred to that the mole of the reactant such as FA conversion per hour over per mole metal site on the surface of catalyst, as shown in the following equations: TOF ( h - 1 ) = n initial - n final n M × t × 100 % n M = w × m cat × Dis M / M M Here ninitial is the initial moles of reactant, nfinal is the final moles of reactant, nM is the moles of exposed metal atom, w is the mass fraction of metal in the catalyst, mcat is the mass of the catalyst, DisM is the dispersion of metal, and MM is the molar mass of metal. For the recyclability test, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation, then washed for several times with ethanol and dried for the next run. 2.4 Structural characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were operated under 40 mA and 30 kV on a Japan Rigaku D/Max 2550VB + 18 kW diffractometer (Cu Ka radiation) at the range of 5 to 90° with a scanning rate of 10° min−1. A field emission SEM (Zeiss Gemini 300) was used to characterize the specific morphologies. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was measured on a FEI Tecnai F20 ST microscope under 200 kV to observe the morphologies and detailed microstructure. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were obtained from a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer under 77 K. The pore size distribution was calculated by using the Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, and the BET method was employed to determine the specific surface area of the samples. The surface elemental composition and element valence distribution were detected by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer with Al Kα X-ray radiation as the X-ray source for excitation. H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and H2 temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) were carried out on a Micromeritics 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). In detail, the sample (50 mg) was pretreated at 200 °C for 1 h in N2 and then cooled to 25 °C. The H2-TPR data were obtained by introducing 10 vol% H2/N2 into the reactor and the temperature was increased from 25 °C to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. As to H2-TPD, sufficient H2 was injected at 25 °C until adsorption saturation, followed by purging with N2 (30 mL/min) at 25°C for about 2 h. The temperature was then increased from 25 °C to 500 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min to obtain H2-TPD data. Additionally, CO pulse chemisorption was measured on ChemBET-300, the catalysts were pretreated with He (30 mL/min) at 200 °C for 1 h and then cooled to 193 K under He flow, followed by changing the He flow to 15 vol% CO/He and kept for 1 h. The element content was measured on ICS-1100 (Thermal-Fisher, USA) with ICP-OES method. The in situ FT-IR spectra experiment were carried out by the Thermo Scientific/ NiColet iS50. In the case of FA, FOL and CO adsorption, the catalysts were treated in Ar at 200 °C for 0.5 h to acquire the reference signal. Then FA or FOL were introduced into the reactor for 0.5 h at 110 °C (The CO was introduced into the reactor for 0.5 h at 30 °C), and Ar gas was purged to remove the physically adsorbed molecule followed by the collection of IR signals. Then, H2 flow was introduced into the in-situ cell to record the reaction process. FT-IR spectra then were recorded at 0, 2, 4, 6 and 8 min, respectively. 2.5 Computational methods All density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the DMol3 theory package in Materials Studio. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the exchange − correlation functional of Perdew − Burke − Ernzerhof (PBE) was used to solve electronic exchange and correlation effects. The model systems used terminated metal surfaces from 5 × 5 surface pristine cells and 15 Å of vacuum space. The structural optimization of catalyst models was performed by the self-consistent direct field (SCF) procedure, in which the convergence threshold, convergence in energy, max force, and displacement were set to 10-5 au, 2 × 10-5 Ha, 0.004 Ha·Å−1 and 0.005 Å, respectively. The adsorption energy of the reaction intermediate was defined as Eads = Eadsorbate+surface − Eadsorbate − Ecleansurface. Furthermore, in order to determine the accurate activation barriers of the reactions, complete LST/QST approach is chosen to search for transition states. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization results of the samples The preparation route of xCoyNi/C catalyst is presented in Fig. 1 a. The contents of Co and Ni in the catalyst were analyzed by ICP-OES, and the actual values are similar to the theoretical values (Table S1). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images of Co/C, 1Co1Ni/C and Ni/C are shown in Fig. 1. It can be seen that the lattice spacings of 0.206 nm, 0.204 nm and 0.201 nm in the Co/C, 1Co1Ni/C and Ni/C catalysts (Fig. 1b-d) correspond to the (111) plane of Co nanoparticles, CoNi alloy nanoparticles and Ni nanoparticles, respectively [24,25,35]. In addition, the elemental line scanning profile of the nanoparticle is shown in Fig. 1e. It can be seen that the 1Co1Ni/C shows a good fit to the signal values of Co and Ni. Furthermore, EDX-mapping measurements were performed to further explore the distribution of elements in 1Co1Ni/C. As shown in Fig. 1f, the Co and Ni elements are evenly distributed and closely overlapped on the carbon substrate, further confirming the formation of the CoNi alloy [36,37]. XRD patterns of the catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 2 . It can be seen that the MOF structure disappears after high-temperature calcination and exhibits distinct metallic peaks (Fig. 2a). Among them, the Co/C catalyst shows obvious metallic Co (JCPDS 15-0806) characteristic diffraction at 2θ = 44.26°, 51.52° and 75.85°, belonging to (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes. Besides, the characteristic diffraction peaks of metallic Ni (JCPDS 87-0712) for Ni/C at 2θ = 44.50°, 51.85° and 76.37° are assigned to the (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes, respectively. Obviously, the diffraction peaks of the (111) crystal planes of the bimetallic catalyst shift to the right with the increase of Ni content and the diffraction peaks are between 44.26–44.50°, suggesting the formation of the CoNi alloy (Fig. 2b) [38], which is consistent with the HR-TEM results. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was carried out for Co-MOF, 1Co1Ni-MOF, Ni-MOF, Co/C, 1Co1Ni/C and Ni/C in Fig. S1. As can be seen from Fig. S1, the catalysts exhibit a clear lamellar structure and the lamellar structure is retained after pyrolysis at high temperature. The layered structure can increase the specific surface area and expose more active sites of the catalyst to improve the catalytic performance [39]. The microstructures of the catalysts were studied by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) in Fig. S2. The PSD histograms fitted by Gaussian show that the Ni/C exhibits the largest nanoparticles (20.87 nm), the size of CoNi alloy in 1Co1Ni/C decreases (15.76 nm) and Co/C presents the smallest particle size (8.97 nm). It is due to the fact that the Ni nanoparticles with large surface energy exist as an energy unstable state on the surface of carbon support, resulting in the easy sintering during heat treatment. This phenomenon is consistent with previous reports [30,40]. In addition, the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm spectra in Fig. S3 show that the catalysts possess a typical type IV adsorption model and H4 hysteresis loop, with complex pore structure of micropore and mesopore [41]. As shown in Table S1, the specific surface area decreases with the increment of Ni content, the reason may be the blockage of the pores by large metal nanoparticles. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out to elucidate the chemical state of the elements in the catalysts (Fig. 3 and Fig. S4). Co, Ni, C and O can be distinguished in the XPS spectra of Co/C, 1Co1Ni/C and Ni/C, respectively (Fig. S4a). As shown in Fig. 3a, the Co 2p peak can be deconvoluted into four peaks, belonging to Co0, Co3+, Co2+ and satellite peak [42]. Notably, the Co0 peak of 1Co1Ni/C (778.11 eV for Co0) shifts to lower binding energy in comparison with Co/C (778.49 eV for Co0). In addition, Fig. 3b shows that the Ni 2p peak can be deconvoluted into three peaks, attributing to Ni0, Ni2+ and satellite peak [8]. The binding energy of Ni0 peak in 1Co1Ni/C (853.70 eV) is higher than that of Ni/C (853.21 eV for Ni0), indicating the formation of CoNi alloy and strong electron transfer from Ni to Co [43]. The detailed data of Co 2p3/2 and Ni 2p3/2 are listed in Table S2. Furthermore, in situ FT-IR spectra of CO adsorption was performed to characterize the electronic properties of Co/C and 1Co1Ni/C catalysts in Fig. S5. For 1Co1Ni/C, the peak at 1930 cm−1 is assigned to bridged CO, the peak at 2012 cm−1 is corresponded to linearly adsorbed CO on metal, while the peaks at 2172 and 2112 cm−1 are associated with CO physical adsorption [44]. Compared with the Co/C spectrum, 1Co1Ni/C shows a red-shift of CO adsorption peaks, suggesting a strong electronic back-donation to the 2π* molecular orbitals of CO due to the transfer of electrons from Ni to Co [45]. Intermetallic electron transfer may lead to electron readjustment on metal surfaces, usually making the metal particles more stable and resulting in higher catalytic performance [21]. Besides, the O 1s XPS spectra are fitted into three peaks at 529.65, 531.79 and 533.60 eV, corresponding to the M-O, C=O and O=C-O (Fig. S4b) [43]. 3.2 Catalytic performances To evaluate the catalytic performances of as-prepared catalysts, hydrogenation of FA was carried out at 110 °C and 2 MPa H2 (Table 1 ). The Co/C achieves 100 % conversion, while the selectivity to TFOL is only 61 %, and the FOL is not detected in the product (Table 1, Entry 1). And a large number of over-hydrogenation and ring-opening products were detected based on the GC-MS analysis when Co/C was used as catalyst, including 2-methyltetrahydrofuran, 1-pentanol, 1, 5-pentanediol, etc (Fig. S6 and Fig. S7). This indicates that Co/C exhibits high catalytic activity with many by-products so as to low TFOL selectivity. In order to enhance the selectivity to TFOL, Ni was introduced to construct Co-Ni bimetallic alloy catalysts. Notably, the introduction of Ni greatly increases the yield of TFOL and inhibits the by-products (Table 1, Entries 2–3). When the molar ratio of Co to Ni was 1:1 (1Co1Ni/C), the TFOL yield reaches 89 % (Table 1, Entry 3). However, as the Ni content continues to increase, the TFOL yield decreases and the FOL yield increases (Table 1, Entry 4). When Ni/C was used as the catalyst, the conversion decreases to 93 % (Table 1, Entry 5), indicating that the catalytic activity of Ni is lower than that of Co. Additionally, the catalytic reaction was carried out over equal masses physical mixture of Co/C and Ni/C. The selectivity to TFOL is only 79 %, indicating that the synergistic effect between Co and Ni plays an important role in FA hydrogenation to TFOL (Table 1, Entry 6). Besides, the FA conversion over the 1Co1Ni/C was only 19 % in the N2 atmosphere, indicating the existence of slight transfer hydrogenation (Table 1, Entry 7). In general, the carbon derived from different materials has a great influence on the catalytic performance. We prepared other catalysts using activated carbon and cellulose as carbon sources, the results are shown in Entries 8–9 in Table 1. As shown in Fig. 3 and Fig. S8, the carbon derived from different materials affects the reduction of metal oxides and intermetallic electron transfer, which may have a significant impact on the catalytic performance. Typically, in FA hydrogenation, temperature and pressure have important effects on product selectivity. As shown in Fig. S9a, the conversion of FA was lower and FOL was the main product over 1Co1Ni/C under lower reaction temperature (90 °C). With the increment of reaction temperature, FOL yield gradually decreases and TFOL yield gradually increases. However, as the temperature rises to 120 °C, TFOL selectivity decreases and other products increase. Meanwhile, the effect of pressure is similar to that of temperature (Fig. S9b), and too much higher pressure will lead to the production of by-products (3 MPa). This indicates that temperature and pressure have important effects on the catalytic activity and TFOL selectivity during FA conversion. Finally, we chose 110 °C and 2 MPa H2 pressure as the optimum reaction conditions for 1Co1Ni/C catalyst. To further elucidate the effect of different catalysts on the hydrogenation activity, H2-TPR and H2-TPD analysis were performed. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the hydrogen consumption peaks around 485 °C are the reduction peak of Co2+ to Co0 and Ni2+ to Ni0 [29,46]. Noticeably, the temperature of the reduction peaks decreases with the increment of the Ni content, indicating that the addition of Ni promotes the reduction of the metal [35]. This could be ascribed to the hydrogen spillover from metallic nickel particles to cobalt oxides, promoting reduction of Co by the interaction between Ni and Co [47]. In addition, the 1Co1Ni/C catalyst has the lowest hydrogen consumption, indicating that more metal oxides have been reduced to metal active sites by carbon during the pyrolysis process in comparison with other samples (Table S1). As observed in Fig. 4b, the Co/C, 3Co1Ni/C and 1Co1Ni/C have strong hydrogen desorption peaks at 364 °C, 371 °C and 375 °C respectively, corresponding to the desorption peak of H-H splitting on the surface of metal particles [22,48]. It can be seen that the desorption peak moves towards higher temperature with the increment of Ni content. In general, desorption temperature represents the binding strength of hydrogen on the catalyst, indicating that the 1Co1Ni/C catalyst has stronger binding capability with H atom in comparison with Co/C [49,50]. The strong adsorption of H atom on the surface of the catalyst does not release active hydrogen too quickly, leading to over-hydrogenation, which is confirmed by the experimental results (Table 1, Entries 1–3). Contrarily, no obvious hydrogen overflow peak appears in the 1Co3Ni/C and Ni/C samples, indicating that Ni exhibits negligible hydrogen dissociation ability and it has to be modified by enough Co to increase the hydrogen dissociation capacity [4,34]. In order to better understand the reaction process of FA hydrogenation, the reaction kinetics over different catalysts were studied. As observed in Fig. 5 a, FA is completely converted after 4 h. Accordingly, FA is rapidly converted into FOL within 1 h, and the FOL is further hydrogenated to TFOL, and finally the yield of TFOL reaches a maximum of > 99 % at 6 h. Hence, it is reasonable to believe that FOL is an intermediate product in the reaction process. To further verify the reaction process, FOL was employed as initial reactant in the reaction over 1Co1Ni/C catalyst (Fig. 5b). It can be seen that the conversion reaches 100 % after 5 h. Meanwhile, FOL is rapidly converted to TFOL and no other products are detected. Based on the above experimental results, it can be seen that FA is firstly turned into FOL via C = O hydrogenation, and then the FOL is converted into TFOL via ring hydrogenation (Fig. 5e). This result is consistent with the literature [13,14]. Moreover, the kinetics of FA hydrogenation over Co/C and Ni/C are shown in Fig. 5c and d. Compared with 1Co1Ni/C and Ni/C, the full conversion of FA over Co/C catalyst is faster, indicating that Co/C possesses higher catalytic activity. Furthermore, CO pulse chemisorption is carried out to quantitatively analyze the active adsorption sites, metal surface area, and metal dispersion of the catalysts (Table S1). The results show that the metal dispersion and the metal surface area decrease with the increment of Ni content. Accordingly, we calculate the turn over frequency (TOF) of FA over Co/C, 1Co1Ni/C and Ni/C in Fig. S10, the TOF value decreases with the increment of Ni content and Ni/C shows the lowest reaction rate. Although Co/C exhibits the fastest rate, the selectivity to TFOL is relatively low due to over-hydrogenation (Fig. 5c and Fig. S6). These results reveal that the high activity of Co/C may lead to the undifferentiated activation of functional groups in FA, and the alloy effect can appropriately reduce the reaction rate to allow the two-step hydrogenation of FA to proceed smoothly and increase the TFOL yield. As mentioned above, the conversion of FA to TFOL is a two-step process. To better reveal the selectivity to TFOL in the two-step reaction, the adsorption experiments of FA via in situ FT-IR analysis were carried out. It can be seen from Fig. S11, Co/C, Ni/C and 1Co1Ni/C show a red shift in the v(C = O) site in comparison with gaseous adsorbed FA. Notably, v(C = O) exhibits a distinct red shift over Co/C in comparison with Ni/C and 1Co1Ni/C, indicating that v(C = O) presents stronger chemisorption on Co/C, thus causing the O atom to fall off with high activity [14]. On the contrary, 1Co1Ni/C presents a suitable adsorption strength for v(C = O), which favors the conversion of FA to FOL. In addition, Co/C, Ni/C and 1Co1Ni/C show a slight red shift in the furan ring and v(C = C) sites in comparison with gaseous adsorbed FA, suggesting the interactions between the catalysts and the furan ring. After the adsorption of FA on the surface of the catalysts, H2 was introduced into the reactor at 120 °C and FT-IR spectra were collected to monitor FA hydrogenation process. For Co/C sample (Fig. 6 a), the three bands assigned to v(C = O), v(C = C) and furan ring decrease rapidly along with the input of hydrogen and a new band (1076 cm−1) attributed to v(C-O) appears and then disappears rapidly [51]. It indicates that furfural is strongly parallel adsorbed on Co/C and the C-O bond in furfural molecule is also strongly adsorbed on the catalyst surface, leading to deoxygenation and ring-opening products. For the 1Co1Ni/C catalyst, the three bands of v(C = O), v(C = C) and furan ring slowly decrease with the introduction of hydrogen, while the newly appeared v(C-O) peak is gradually strengthened, and the peak signal can still be detected at 8 min (Fig. 6b). It can be seen that furfural also tends to adsorb in parallel on 1Co1Ni/C, but the adsorption strength of the furan ring and v(C-O) is weaker than that on Co/C, thus inhibiting the formation of by-products. As the most important intermediate in FA hydrogenation to TFOL, the adsorption states of FOL over Co/C, Ni/C and 1Co1Ni/C are shown in Fig. S12. The gaseous adsorbed FOL shows strong peaks at 1570 cm−1, 1474 cm−1, 1161 cm−1, 1088 cm−1 and 1014 cm−1, which are attributed to furan ring breath, v(C = C), vas (C-O-C), v(C-O) and vs (C-O-C) on the furan ring, respectively [18,21]. Compared with Co/C, Ni/C and gaseous adsorbed FOL, the adsorption peak of v(C = C) on 1Co1Ni/C exhibits an obvious red-shift, which is attributed to the effect of C = C group in FOL. The adsorption of 1Co1Ni/C is more conducive to the hydrogenation of furan ring. Additionally, 1Co1Ni/C exhibits a weak adsorption of vas (C-O-C), v(C-O) and vs (C-O-C). With the introduction of hydrogen, the bands of vas (C-O-C), v(C-O) and vs (C-O-C) decline rapidly and simultaneously disappear after 8 min on Co/C (Fig. 6c). Considering the in situ FT-IR of furfural and catalytic performance, it can be seen that excessive hydrogenation and ring-opening products form and desorb from the surface of Co. In the case of 1Co1Ni/C (Fig. 6d), the vas (C-O-C) and vs (C-O-C) peak signals slowly decrease and disappear after 8 min while the v(C-O) signal is still detectable, suggesting that the 1Co1Ni/C is more favorable for the hydrogenation of the furan ring and inhibits C-O adsorption. According to the above in situ FT-IR analysis, the distinct adsorption configurations of FA and FOL on 1Co1Ni/C resulted in the selective conversion of FA to TFOL due to electron redistribution of CoNi alloy surface. To demonstrate the role of the catalyst, 1Co1Ni/C was filtered out at the conversion of 57.51 %, and the filtrate continued to react with no increase in conversion (Fig. S13a). The recycle tests show that there is no significant change in catalytic performance after six cycles (Fig. S13b). The Co and Ni contents of the recycled 1Co1Ni/C catalyst were determined to be 33.1 wt% and 30.9 wt%, suggesting almost no change in comparison with the initial contents (i.e., 33.6 wt% and 31.2 wt%). Furthermore, XRD, N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm and XPS analysis of the used 1Co1Ni/C display no obvious change in comparison with the fresh catalyst. (Fig. S14). 3.3 DFT calculations As can be seen from the above studies, the synergistic effect between Co and Ni can effectively modulate the adsorption of specific functional groups, hence improving the selectivity to TFOL. To further figure out the effect of Co and Ni alloy, theoretical calculations were carried out. Based on the XRD and TEM characterization results, the Co (111), Ni (111) and 1Co1Ni (111) catalyst models are established in Fig. S15. Firstly, perpendicular and parallel adsorption models of FA are placed in different sites on Co (111), Ni (111) and 1Co1Ni (111) facets, respectively (Fig. S16). Furthermore, Fig. 7 shows the calculation results of FA adsorption energy on Co (111), Ni (111) and Co or Ni site of 1Co1Ni (111) facets. And the bond distances (in Å) of adsorption models are summarized in Table S3. As shown in Fig. 7, the FA molecule on Co (111), Ni (111) and 1Co1Ni (111) crystal surfaces prefers to adsorb in parallel state after the computational model optimization, which is consistent with the in situ FT-IR results. Furthermore, the adsorption energies of the FA molecule on Co (111) and Ni (111) facet in the perpendicular and parallel states are −1.14, −1.46, −0.81, and −0.86 eV, respectively, indicating that the Co (111) facet presents higher adsorption energy of the FA molecule than that on the Ni (111) facet. As shown in the experimental results, the exorbitant adsorption energy on Co (111) facet leads to over-hydrogenation or ring-opening of FA, hence reduces the selectivity to TFOL. It is worth noting that the adsorption energies of the FA molecule on Co site of 1Co1Ni (111) facet are lower (−1.10 and −1.30 eV) than those on Co (111) facet. On the contrary, the adsorption energies of the FA molecule on Ni site of 1Co1Ni (111) facet are higher (−0.98 and −0.99 eV) than those on Ni (111) facet. It indicates that the formation of the CoNi alloy can effectively modulate the adsorption capacity for FA, and 1Co1Ni/C exhibits a suitable adsorption energy for FA molecule so as to avoid over-hydrogenation. Additionally, the FA adsorption on Co site of 1Co1Ni (111) facet in the parallel state is the main adsorption position due to higher adsorption energies than that on Ni site of 1Co1Ni (111) facet. Meanwhile, the adsorption models of the FOL molecule on Co (111), Ni (111) and 1Co1Ni (111) facets are established, respectively (Fig. S17). Fig. 8 shows the calculation results of the FOL adsorption on Co (111, Ni (111) and Co or Ni site of the 1Co1Ni (111) facets in the perpendicular and parallel states. And the bond distances (in Å) of adsorption models are shown in Table S4. Similar to FA adsorption, the FOL molecule also tends to adsorb on Co (111), Ni (111) and 1Co1Ni (111) crystal surfaces in parallel state. The comparison of the adsorption energies of FOL molecule on different adsorption sites revealed that adsorption on Co site of 1Co1Ni (111) facet (−1.15 and −1.22 eV) are lower than those on Co (111) facet (−1.2 and −1.35 eV), while adsorption on Ni site of 1Co1Ni (111) facet (−1.05 and −1.15 eV) are higher than those on Ni (111) facet (−0.92 and −1.11 eV). Thus, the intermediate FOL molecule prefers to adsorb on Co site of 1Co1Ni (111) facet in the parallel state. The suitable adsorption intensity of 1Co1Ni for FOL molecule avoids the ring-opening reaction on Co and incomplete hydrogenation on Ni, and thus 1Co1Ni/C catalyst gives the highest selectivity to TFOL (Table 1). The H2 molecule adsorption models on different positions of Co (111), Ni (111) and 1Co1Ni (111) facets are established in the perpendicular and parallel states to further confirm the adsorption configuration of H2 molecule (Fig. S18). As shown in Fig. S19, the largest H2 adsorption energies on Co (111), Ni (111) and 1Co1Ni (111) facets are −0.35 eV, −0.16 eV and −0.26 eV, respectively. In addition, the H-H bond distances are shown in Table S5. It can be seen that H2 molecule has the largest adsorption energy on Co (111) facet, thus results in relatively fast hydrogenation rate. However, too fast hydrogenation rate, larger adsorption energy of FA and FOL on Co (111) facet, and unsuitable adsorption configuration lead to the formation of ring-opening products (Fig. S6) easily. The 1Co1Ni (111) facet exhibits more suitable adsorption energy for H2 in comparison with Co (111) and Ni (111) facets, thus avoids the formation of ring-opening products. Additionally, as can be seen in Fig. S20, the H* is placed on the bridge, hollow, and top positions of Co (111), Ni (111) and 1Co1Ni (111) facets. The calculation results indicate that Co (111) facet presents the lowest H* adsorption energy, while Ni (111) facet exhibits the largest H* adsorption energy (Fig. S21), corresponding to the fastest and the slowest H* release rate, which are unfavorable for FA hydrogenation to TFOL. Nevertheless, 1Co1Ni (111) facet possesses more suitable adsorption energy of H* in comparison with Co (111) and Ni (111) facets, thus effectively controls the release rate of H* and favors to obtain TFOL. The density of states (DOS) near the Fermi level, which mainly originates from the d state, was further investigated to probe the adsorbate–metal interaction before and after the formation of alloy. Impressively, the d-band center (Ed) of 1Co1Ni (111) facet between Co (111) and Ni (111) facets (Fig. S22), which clearly illustrates that the d-band center changes after alloying. It suggests that the interaction between the adsorbate and surface is regulated, thus affecting the catalytic performance. In addition, as shown in Fig. S23, the total electron density of 1Co1Ni (111) changes significantly in comparison with Co (111) and Ni (111), indicating that alloying strategy can regulate electron distribution on metal surfaces, which is confirmed by the XPS results. The results of transition state search are presented in Fig. 9 and Table S6. As to hydrogenation path over 1Co1Ni (111), the FA hydrogenation to FAH needs to overcome the activation barrier of 1.18 eV (TS1). Then, the hydrogenation of FAH to FOL needs to overcome a barrier of 2.43 eV [12]. Finally, the furan ring of FOL is sequentially hydrogenated to TFOL (TS3, TS4, TS5, TS6) [52]. It can be seen that the pure metal Co can reduce the activation barrier of TS1 and TS2 during the hydrogenation of FA to FOL. However, the 1Co1Ni is able to lower the activation barrier of the hydrogenation of FOL to TFOL, especially the activation barrier of TS3. In other words, alloying strategy can reduce FOL formation rate as well as activate C = C in furan ring to generate TFOL. Above all, the DFT calculation results show that the alloying strategy can effectively optimize the reactants (FA, FOL, H2 and H*) adsorption during FA hydrogenation to TFOL, and reduce the activation barrier from FOL to TFOL and improve the selectivity to TFOL. Meanwhile, the DFT calculation results are in good agreement with the experimental results. 4 Conclusion In summary, the CoNi alloy catalysts (xCoyNi/C) were prepared by one-step pyrolysis of MOFs and applied in FA hydrogenation to TFOL. The electron transfer between Co and Ni leads to reconstruction of the electronic structure on the metal surface, which can regulate the adsorption configuration on the surface of the active center. Characterizations and DFT calculations show that 1Co1Ni/C catalyst exhibits more suitable reactants (FA, TFOL, H2 and H*) adsorption and hydrogenation reaction rate in comparison with monometallic catalysts (Co/C and Ni/C). Meanwhile, transitional state search reveals that 1Co1Ni/C catalyst significantly reduces the activation barrier from FOL to TFOL in comparison with Co/C catalyst. Thus, it can be seen that 1Co1Ni/C gives the highest yield (>99 %) to TFOL. Moreover, 1Co1Ni/C catalyst exhibits excellent recycle performance. This study provides a simple strategy for the preparation of alloy catalysts and obtains an in-depth understanding of the role of CoNi alloy in FA hydrogenation to TFOL, which may bring a bright insight for the upgrade of biomass. coredata.dc:description: The targeted conversion of furfural (FA) over inexpensive catalyst is a critical and challenging project. Herein, CoNi alloy catalysts (xCoyNi/C) were prepared through one-step pyrolysis of metal–organic frameworks and used in furfural (FA) hydrogenation to tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (TFOL). The formation of CoNi alloy leads to a reconfiguration of the electronic structure on the metal surface, which affects the adsorption of functional groups on FA and furfuryl alcohol (FOL). In situ FT-IR analysis and DFT calculations verify that bimetallic CoNi alloy catalyst exhibits more suitable reactants adsorption and hydrogenation rate in comparison with the monometallic Co and monometallic Ni catalysts. Meanwhile, CoNi alloy significantly reduces the activation barrier from FOL to TFOL. Hence, the 1Co1Ni/C catalyst gives the highest TFOL yield of > 99 %. This study provides a simple strategy for the preparation of alloy catalysts for tuning product selectivity and presents practical potential for upgrading biomass-derived platform molecules.
